Please join! \n\nThere has never been a moment when the distance between having an idea and building it has been smaller. Things that required months of work for teams can now be built by individuals using AI, in days. This is why we built DeepLearning.AI Pro. I'm personally working hard on this membership program to help you to build applications that can launch or accelerate your career, and shape the future of AI.\n\nDeepLearning.AI Pro gives you full access to 150+ programs, including my recently launched Agentic AI course, the new Post-Training and PyTorch courses by Sharon Zhou and Laurence Moroney (just released this week), and all of DeepLearning.AI's top courses and professional certificates.\n\nAll course videos remain free. Pro membership adds hands-on learning: labs to build working systems, practice questions to hone your understanding, and certificates to share your skills.\n\nI'm also building new tools to help you create AI applications and grow your career (and have fun doing so!). Many will be available first to Pro members.\n\nTry out DeepLearning.AI Pro free, and let me know what you build!\n\nhttps://lnkd.in/g599YP7E","url":"https://www.linkedin.com/posts/andrewyng_deeplearningai-pro-become-an-ai-builder-activity-7389711321006657536-YHxM"},{"@context":"https://schema.org","@type":"DiscussionForumPosting","author":{"@type":"Person","name":"Andrew Ng","url":"https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrewyng"},"datePublished":"2025-10-29T17:24:18.325Z","headline":"","interactionStatistic":{"@type":"InteractionCounter","interactionType":"http://schema.org/LikeAction","userInteractionCount":3022},"mainEntityOfPage":"https://www.linkedin.com/posts/andrewyng_an-exciting-new-professional-certificate-activity-7389351387760984064-p8C_","text":"An exciting new professional certificate: PyTorch for Deep Learning, taught by Laurence Moroney, is now available at DeepLearning.AI. This is the definitive program for learning PyTorch, which is one of the main frameworks researchers use to build breakthrough AI systems. If you want to understand how modern deep learning models workâor build your own custom architecturesâPyTorch gives you direct control over the key aspects of model development.\n\nThis three-course professional certificate takes you from fundamentals through advanced architectures and deployment:\n\nCourse 1: PyTorch: Fundamentals - Learn how PyTorch represents data with tensors and how datasets fit into the training process. You'll build and train neural networks step by step, monitor training progress, and evaluate performance. By the end, you'll understand PyTorch's workflow and be ready to design, train, and test your own models.\n\nCourse 2: PyTorch: Techniques and Ecosystem Tools - Master hyperparameter optimization, model profiling, and workflow efficiency. You'll use learning rate schedulers, tackle overfitting, and apply automated tuning with Optuna. Work with TorchVision for visual AI and Hugging Face for NLP. Learn transfer learning and fine-tune pretrained models for new problems.\n\nCourse 3: PyTorch: Advanced Architectures and Deployment - Build sophisticated architectures including Siamese Networks, ResNet, DenseNet, and Transformers. Learn how attention mechanisms power modern language models and how diffusion models generate images. I've also seen many applications where post-training is what turns a demo application that works only 80% of the time into a reliable system that consistently performs. The Google Brain team's success was the inspiration for many other companies to build up their own AI teams. <br><br>Using Google's compute infrastructure, we started by proving that scaling up data and compute leads to huge performance improvements, and also created the famous "Google Cat" demonstration of AI learning to recognize objects (such as cats) by itself.           <h3 class="base-aside-card__title font-sans text-md font-bold text-color-text relative">

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          Recently Meta made headlines with unprecedented, massive compensation packages for AI model builders exceeding $100M (sometimes spread over multiple years). With the company planning to spend $66B-72B this year on capital expenses such as data centers, a meaningful fraction of which will be devoted to AI, from a purely financial point of view, itâs not irrational to spend a few extra billion dollars on salaries to make sure this hardware is used well.

A typical software-application startup thatâs not involved in training foundation models might spend 70-80% of its dollars on salaries, 5-10% on rent, and 10-25% on other operating expenses (cloud hosting, software licenses, marketing, legal/accounting, etc.). But scaling up models is so capital-intensive, salaries are a small fraction of the overall expense. This makes it feasible for businesses in this area to pay their relatively few employees exceptionally well. If youâre spending tens of billions of dollars on GPU hardware, why not spend just a tenth of that on salaries? Even before Metaâs recent offers, salaries of AI model trainers have been high, with many being paid $5-10M/year, although Meta has raised these numbers to new heights.

Meta carries out many activities, including run Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp, and Oculus. But the Llama/AI-training part of its operations is particularly capital-intensive. Many of Metaâs properties rely on user-generated content (UGC) to attract attention, which is then monetized through advertising. AI is a huge threat and opportunity: If AI-generated content (AIGC) substitutes for UGC to capture people's attention to sell ads against, this will transform the social-media landscape.

This is why Meta â like TikTok, YouTube, and other social-media properties â is paying close attention to AIGC, and why making significant investments in AI is rational. Further, when Meta hires a key employee, not only does it gain the future work output of that person, but it also gets insight into a competitorâs technology, which also makes its willingness to pay high salaries a rational business move (so long as it does not adversely affect the companyâs culture).

The pattern of capital-intensive businesses compensating employees extraordinarily well is not new. For example, Netflix expects to spend a huge $18B this year on content. This makes the salary expense of paying its 14,000 employees a small fraction of the total expense, which allows the company to routinely pay above-market salaries. Its ability to spend this way also shapes a distinctive culture that includes elements of âweâre a sports team, not a familyâ (which seems to work for Netflix but isnât right for everyone). In contrast, a labor-intensive manufacturing business like Foxconn, which employs over 1 million people, has to be much more price-sensitive in what it pays people.

            </p>

          <h3 class="base-aside-card__title font-sans text-md font-bold text-color-text relative">

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          The resurgence of reinforcement learning is great, but itâs missing the big picture. 

Chasing traditional RL is the wrong direction. In pursuing better policies and reward shaping, itâs easy to miss a simpler tool we already have: language.

There is no reason to work in weights and gradients if you can work in natural language.

Today weâre releasing our first set of research on Prompt Learning â not prompt tuning, not chain-of-thought. Something new.

To our knowledge, no one has yet rigorously researched, characterized, and measured a full implementation of this approach. 

Instead of adjusting weights, we use MetaPrompting â where English evals and critiques (rather than just scalar metrics like previously done by the industry) drive targeted prompt updates.

Itâs a promising avenue of research, and the early results show that it works. Writeup in the comments.
        
            </p>

          <img alt="The resurgence of reinforcement learning is great, but itâs missing the big picture. 

Chasing traditional RL is the wrong direction. In pursuing better policies and reward shaping, itâs easy to miss a simpler tool we already have: language.

There is no reason to work in weights and gradients if you can work in natural language.

Today weâre releasing our first set of research on Prompt Learning â not prompt tuning, not chain-of-thought. Something new.

To our knowledge, no one has yet rigorously researched, characterized, and measured a full implementation of this approach. 

Instead of adjusting weights, we use MetaPrompting â where English evals and critiques (rather than just scalar metrics like previously done by the industry) drive targeted prompt updates.

Itâs a promising avenue of research, and the early results show that it works.             <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          Introducing SemTools - add blazing-fast semantic search to your entire filesystem without a vector database â¡ï¸

Coding agents like Claude Code/Cursor have full access to the CLI like grep, cat, and pipe operations for search. But they lack âproper` semantic search thatâs actually fast. SemTools adds in two additional CLI commands:
1ï¸â£ `parse` for document parsing
2ï¸â£ `search` to dynamically chunk/embed/search in-mem based on any set of files using static embeddings (400x faster than dense).

You can chain these commands with existing operations like grep + pipes. Importantly, you also donât need to maintain a vector db or dense heavyweight embedding models - these are overkill, slower, and probably lower accuracy vs. just a CLI agent which has access to other CLI operations too.

(See Claude code screenshot below with semtools in action - see `parse` and `search` commands used)

This means you can easily give 1k+ PDFs/other docs within your filesystem to your favorite coding agent/general agent, and have it efficiently crunch through any context to pull in just what the agent needs.

Huge shoutout to Logan Markewich. Check it out: https://lnkd.in/gicRBe9D
        
            </p>

        <div class="base-aside-card__info self-center pl-1 flex flex-col flex-1">

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          Google released a new 270M Gemma 3 variant last week, a lightweight, open-weight LLM that's perfect for local fine-tuning experiments and general tinkering. 

I couldn't resist and re-implemented it from scratch in pure PyTorch: https://lnkd.in/gSGzZvZv

A few interesting tidbits about the Gemma 3 architecture:

1) One of the few recent architectures (besides gpt-oss) that uses Sliding Window Attention with a ratio of 5 local to 1 global layers

2) Dual RMSNorm: unlike standard Pre-Norm or Post-Norm transformers, Gemma 3 uses RMSNorm both before and after its attention + MLP blocks (I added the Qwen 3 figure showing the standard placement for comparison)

3) Vocabulary size: similar to other Gemma 3 models, it uses a huge vocabulary (~256k tokens), which should help with better multilingual coverage

The code in my notebook requires about 1.49 GB of RAM (for inference) and runs comfortably on a laptop / Mac Mini.

(Note that while it has good instruction-following capabilities given its small size, it's of course not a go-to model for local inference; the focus is more on being fast and lightweight for research and experimentation purposes.)

Happy tinkering!
        
            </p>

          ð New Survey on Retrieval And Structuring Augmented Generation (RAS) with LLMs

Large Language Models are powerful, but they still struggle with hallucinations, outdated knowledge, and limited domain expertise.

This new survey from KDDâ25 takes a deep dive into how Retrieval And Structuring (RAS) Augmented Generation can address those gaps.

The paper explores:

- Retrieval methods (sparse, dense, hybrid)
- Structuring techniques (taxonomy, hierarchical classification, information extraction)
- Integration with LLMs (prompt-based, reasoning frameworks, embeddings)
- Open challenges (retrieval efficiency, structure quality, knowledge integration)
- Future directions (multimodal retrieval, cross-lingual structures, interactive systems)

If youâre working on RAG, knowledge graphs, or structured reasoning with LLMs, this survey is a must-read.
        
            </p>

          An interesting new paper on LLM-JEPA from Hai Huang, Yann LeCun, and Randall Balestriero. ð¡ Previously I wrote about JEPA approach applied to videos (V-JEPA and V-JEPA 2) and time series (CHARM). Now the JEPA approach is finally applied to LLMs!

This work bridges a major gap between AI for vision and language, offering a potential leap forward in how we train language models. Instead of just predicting the next word, LLM-JEPA teaches models to understand the underlying meaning by predicting abstract concepts (as JEPA approach does)âfor instance, grasping the essence of a code snippet from its natural language description.

The paper introduces a hybrid objective combining standard next-token prediction with a Joint Embedding Predictive Architecture (JEPA) loss, a technique highly successful in computer vision. The empirical results are compelling: LLM-JEPA consistently boosts performance, accelerates parameter-efficient fine-tuning (PEFT), and shows remarkable resistance to overfitting. This method doesn't just improve scores; it fundamentally creates more structured and transferable representations. While the current computational overhead is a challenge to address, this paper opens a promising new direction beyond traditional LLM training. ð

Review: https://lnkd.in/eC4Jte_r
Paper: https://lnkd.in/erZJadb3

            </p>

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          ð§  What if âthinking harderâ makes large language models worse at following instructions?
We seek to answer this question in our paper âWhen Thinking Fails: The Pitfalls of Reasoning for Instruction-Following in LLMsâ that has been accepted as a Spotlight at NeurIPS 2025! ð
Reasoning is often seen as the âsecret sauceâ for improving large language models. But what if more thinking doesnât always mean better following? ð¤
In this work, we uncover a surprising phenomenon: adding explicit reasoning (like chain-of-thought) can actually hurt instruction-following. Across 15 models and two rigorous benchmarks, we found that reasoning sometimes distracts models from the very constraints theyâre supposed to respect.
To dig deeper, we introduce constraint attention â a way to measure how much focus models devote to instructions themselves â and show why reasoning goes astray. Even more exciting, we propose methods (like classifier-selective reasoning) that recover lost performance and point to better ways of making LLMs both effective reasoners and instruction followers.
Huge thanks to my co-authors Xiaomin Li, Zhou Yu, Zhiwei Zhang, Xupeng Chen, Ziji Zhang, Yingying Zhuang, and Anurag B..
Excited to dive into this discussion with the community this December!
ð Full paper: arxiv.org/abs/2505.11423
#NeurIPS2025 #LLMs #Reasoning #InstructionFollowing #MachineLearning
        
            </p>

        <div class="base-aside-card__info self-center pl-1 flex flex-col flex-1">
          <h3 class="base-aside-card__title font-sans text-md font-bold text-color-text relative">
            
<!---->          </h3>

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          Investment is moving from pre-training to post-training. Early LLM budgets focused on training ever-larger base models. Post-deployment, models were mostly fixed... improvements came via scaling next-gen models. Now labs split resources between pre-training and RL fine-tuning with careful inference optimization. In post-training, models learn reasoning, follow prefs and refine outputs for specific tasks. Models update more frequently, weekly or monthly vs yearly.

Each iteration collects new data, extends RL training and adjusts rewards to improve reasoning. New economic models charge for updated reasoning engines vs static models. Serving costs and latency are key so providers favor efficient pro models with most accuracy at lower compute.

3 more takeaways from ICML:

1ï¸â£ RL is only beginning to cross into âunverifiableâ domains.
Traditional RL used tasks with clear auto checks (like code compilers or math calcs) for rewards. Domains like Math Olympiad or legal arguments have complex solutions that can't be auto-verified. These need more complex reward models scoring reasoning steps, argument clarity or persuasiveness vs just correctness. With solid reward models, RL could teach coherent proofs, experiment design or legal strategies. This is still early work - current systems often break tasks into verifiable parts or use human prefs, but broader paths are emerging.

2ï¸â£ Personalization is a safer near-term goal than true continual learning.
Interest in adapting models to users is growing with 2 key approaches. Personalization tailors outputs by learning user-specific rewards from few feedbacks or adding curiosity rewards that prompt questions about user tastes. These adjust behavior without changing model weights, improving perceived helpfulness and empathy. Continual learning updates parameters in real time from all user input. But continual learning poses safety and privacy risks like overfitting, bias amp & data leakage. Personalization and context windows (remembering interactions without weight changes) are more practical and responsible.

3ï¸â£ RL scaling will follow multiple paths.
â One path applies current RL methods (PPO, guided reward models, diffusion reg) to more domains. This incremental path needs no new algos, just better rewards, bigger varied datasets & optimization tweaks. 

â The second tackles sparse-reward probs with long feedback delays. Success depends on credit assignment in long seqs and off-policy learning using varied experiences. Off-policy RL supports multi-datacenter training with clusters handling acting, collection and learning. 

â The third involves continual learning with frequent updates using user feedback and new data.

Each has trade-offs: incremental and safe, risky but domain-expanding, adaptive but complex w/ safety issues.

What'd I miss?
        
            </p>

        <div class="base-aside-card__info self-center pl-1 flex flex-col flex-1">
          <h3 class="base-aside-card__title font-sans text-md font-bold text-color-text relative">
            
<!---->          </h3>

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          Memory is becoming the new infrastructure layer of AI.

Every week, new frameworks emerge promising to fix the same fundamental problem: LLMs forget too quickly, and retrieval systems canât keep up with the complexity of real work.

Letâs break down a few of the most influential approaches â and where they still fall short:

ð¹ REFRAG (Meta + NUS) â Instead of stuffing long documents directly into context, it compresses retrieval chunks into embeddings, reducing latency and context bloat. Smart for efficiency, but still struggles with knowledge integration: how do you connect ideas across multiple documents, not just compress them?
ð¹ KG-RAG (Adobe Research) â Builds structured knowledge graphs out of enterprise docs. Great for reducing hallucination and noise, but graph construction is brittle and costly. Updating ontologies fast enough for dynamic teams remains unsolved.
ð¹ Human-Inspired Frameworks (SALM, CAIM, PREMem) â Bring in concepts like episodic, semantic, and procedural memory. These are closer to how humans think, shifting some reasoning into memory itself. But theyâre mostly research-grade, not production-ready: integration into daily team workflows is minimal.
ð¹ System-Level OS Approaches (MemOS, MemoryOS) â Treat memory like an operating system, with lifecycle management, scheduling, and migration across âshort-term,â âmid-term,â and âlong-termâ layers. Strong architectural vision, but too abstract for non-research teams who just want answers today, not a full OS overhaul.
ð¹ Social & Group Memory (Social-RAG) â Retrieves not just facts but social context from group interactions. Crucial for collaboration use cases, but limited to niche scenarios right now.

Across all of these, two unsolved challenges keep coming up:

Integration vs. Efficiency â Compressing memory helps scale, but often destroys the relational context teams actually need.
Lifecycle & Evolution â Few frameworks handle the reality that knowledge is constantly being updated, contradicted, and reshaped.

ð¡ Why Tanka takes a different path
 Instead of treating memory as just a retrieval hack, Tanka treats it as the native infrastructure of work.
Every message, doc, and decision is captured once, then structured into living memory â automatically.
Agents donât just retrieve snippets; they act on evolving context, update it, and carry it across workflows.
Memory isnât abstracted away into embeddings or graphs nobody sees â itâs visible, searchable, and agent-actionable.
For teams drowning in information every day â switching between Slack, Notion, Google Docs, and email â this difference is existential.

Most frameworks solve part of the puzzle. Tanka solves the team problem: how do we stop losing context every time someone leaves, a tool changes, or a project shifts?

The answer: memory-native collaboration.
 Because the future of work isnât just about smarter AI â itâs about AI that never forgets.
        
            </p>

          Most AI agents donât fail because they canât do something. They fail because they canât do it reliably.

            <p class="base-aside-card__subtitle font-sans text-sm text-color-text leading-regular break-words overflow-anywhere
                line-clamp-2">
              
          ð Context Engineering: The Science Behind Smarter LLMs

ð Just finished reading âA Survey of Context Engineering for Large Language Modelsâ â and itâs a game-changer for anyone working with or building LLM systems.

ð¡ Key Takeaways:

ð¹ Context Engineering is more than prompt design. Itâs the formal optimization of the information payload that LLMs consume â including retrieval, formatting, memory, and orchestration.

ð¹ A Unified Framework:
The paper breaks down Context Engineering into 3 foundational components:
	1.	Context Retrieval & Generation â e.g., Prompting, RAG, Dynamic Assembly
	2.	Context Processing â e.g., Long-sequence modeling (Mamba, FlashAttention), Self-Refinement (Reflexion, Self-RAG)
	3.	Context Management â e.g., Compression (H2O, QwenLong), Memory Architectures (MemGPT, MemoryBank)

These are then integrated into powerful systems:
	â¢	RAG 2.0+: Agentic RAG, GraphRAG, Modular RAG
	â¢	Memory-Augmented Agents: Like MemOS and RecMind
	â¢	Tool-Integrated Reasoning: Think Toolformer, AutoGen
	â¢	Multi-Agent Systems: CAMEL, SagaLLM, CrewAI

ð Why it matters:
	â¢	18x gains in information navigation
	â¢	Up to 94% task success rates using context optimization
	â¢	Models learn, reflect, and self-improve without retraining
	â¢	Enables real-time tool use and long-term memory across tasks

â ï¸ Biggest Challenge Identified:
Despite advances in understanding complex context, LLMs still struggle to generate equally complex, structured long-form outputs. Bridging this gap is a priority for future research.

ð Whatâs Next?
	â¢	Scalable architectures with context compression
	â¢	Unified benchmarks for evaluating tool use and memory
	â¢	Human-AI collaboration powered by multimodal, structured, and self-optimizing systems

If youâre building context-aware LLMs, designing retrieval strategies, or exploring multi-agent orchestration â this paper is a must-read.
